description.narrative:
The global humanitarian system is overstretched; unable to meet rising needs of crisis affected countries, and providing assistancethat is often insufficient, inappropriate and late. There is growing support for a shift of power and resources to local actors. Local actors are the first responders when crisis hits and know the local context better than internationals, and yet receive a tiny fraction of international aid.
This program sets out to turn this system on its head and allow vulnerable peoplein disaster prone countries to benefit from better humanitarian response. We have chosen to focus on Bangladesh and Uganda, two countries acutely at risk from humanitarian crises. The frequency and impact of disasters in both countries is being exacerbated by climate change.
To achieve this transformation, Oxfam will strengthen the capacity of local humanitarian actors, so that they can lead humanitarian action in their countries. We will also give them the space to create a strong domestic humanitarian agenda, by giving them the opportunityto design and implement quality humanitarian programs. The program will also influence other international NGOs and donors to contribute to this systemic change.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Novib was founded in 1956 as the Netherlands Organisation for International Assistance (Novib), and joined forces with Oxfam in 1994. Oxfam Novib is member of the Oxfam International confederation. Working together in the confederation, the Oxfam affiliates can speak with one clear and compelling voice on issues of global concern: climate change, health and education for all, agriculture, trade, and conflicts and emergencies. Oxfam Novib's main office is based in The Netherlands, it supports the work of a network of local offices, the implementation of global projects, fundraising, campaigning and advocacy. Oxfam Novib’s the Hague office contributes towards this project’s implementation.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to life and security
